unnormalised: The sun beat down on Kamal's back as he surveyed his field in Maharashtra. Unlike his father, who swore by chemical fertilizers and pesticides, Kamal had decided to embrace organic farming. It wasn't an easy decision. His father, a seasoned farmer with 40 years of experience, had scoffed, "Organic? You'll get nothing! It's all a fad, Kamal. Yield will plummet, and you'll be begging for Rs. 10 to feed your family."

Unlike his father, who swore by chemical fertilizers and pesticides, Kamal had decided to embrace organic farming. It wasn't an easy decision. His father, a seasoned farmer with forty years of experience, had scoffed, "Organic? You'll get nothing! It's all a fad, Kamal. Yield will plummet, and you'll be begging for rupees ten to feed your family."

unnormalised: But Kamal was convinced. He had attended a workshop at the Mahatma Phule Krishi Vidyapeeth in Rahuri, where Dr. Patil had passionately explained the long-term benefits of organic methods: healthier soil, better water retention, and ultimately, higher market value for the produce. He learned about composting, using cow dung and kitchen waste to enrich the soil naturally. He experimented with neem oil as a natural pesticide, a far cry from the harsh chemicals his father used.

He learned about composting, using cow dung and kitchen waste to enrich the soil naturally. He experimented with neem oil as a natural pesticide, a far cry from the harsh chemicals his father used.

unnormalised: The initial results were disheartening. In the first season, his yield was indeed lower, almost 30% less than his father's field planted with the same variety of rice. Doubts crept in. Was his father right? Was he making a huge mistake? His wife, Priya, supported him, reminding him of his commitment to a healthier future for their children.

unnormalised: He persevered, consulting with local organic farming experts and spending hours researching online. He discovered the importance of crop rotation and intercropping. He planted marigolds among his vegetables to repel pests and increased the area dedicated to composting to 500 sq ft. Gradually, things began to change.
normalised: He persevered, consulting with local organic farming experts and spending hours researching online. He discovered the importance of crop rotation and intercropping. He planted marigolds among his vegetables to repel pests and increased the area dedicated to composting to five hundred square feet. Gradually, things began to change.

unnormalised: The soil felt richer, more alive. Earthworms, once scarce, were now abundant. His plants seemed stronger, more resilient. And slowly, the yield began to improve. By the third season, he was almost at par with his father's output. But the real victory came when he sold his organic rice at the local mandi for a premium. The buyers, aware of the growing demand for organic produce, were willing to pay significantly more.

unnormalised: Kamal knew he had a long way to go. He envisioned converting his entire 5-acre farm to organic methods and inspiring other farmers in his village to do the same. His journey had just begun, but the seeds of change were firmly planted.
